text: Restraining the Tongue

Not many should become teachers, my brothers, \add because you\add*\ef + \fr 3:1 \ft ﻿*Here “\add because\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“know”) which is understood as causal \ef* know that we will receive a greater judgment.\f + \fr 3:1 \ft Or “greater condemnation” \f*

For we all stumble \add in\add* many \add ways\add*. If anyone does not stumble in what he says, he \add is\add* a perfect individual,\f + \fr 3:2 \ft Literally “man,” but clearly in a generic sense here meaning “someone, a person” \f* able to hold in check his whole body also.
And if we put bits in the mouths of horses so that they obey us, we also guide their whole bodies.
Behold also ships: \add although they\add* are so large and are driven by strong winds, they are guided by a very small rudder wherever the inclination of the pilot wishes.

So also the tongue is a small member \add of the body\add*\ef + \fr 3:5 \ft ﻿*The words “of the body” are not in the Greek text but are supplied for clarity \ef* and boasts great \add things\add*. Behold how small a fire sets ablaze how great a forest!

And the tongue \add is\add* a fire! The world of unrighteousness,\f + \fr 3:6 \ft Or “a fire, the world of unrighteousness! The tongue is set among our members” \f* the tongue, is set among our members, defiling the whole body and setting on fire ⸤the course of human existence⸥\f + \fr 3:6 \ft Literally “the wheel of origin” \f*, being set on fire by hell.
For every species of animals and birds, of reptiles and sea creatures, is being tamed and has been tamed by the human species,
but no human being is able to tame the tongue. \add It is\add* a restless evil, full of deadly poison.

With it we bless the\ef + \fr 3:9 \ft ﻿*Or possibly “our,” if the Greek article is understood as a possessive pronoun \ef* Lord and Father, and with it we curse people who are made in the likeness of God.
From the same mouth come blessing and cursing. My brothers, these \add things\add* ought not to be so!
A spring does not pour forth from the same opening fresh and bitter \add water, does it\add*?\ef + \fr 3:11 \ft *The negative construction in Greek anticipates a negative answer here \ef*
A fig tree is not able, my brothers, to produce olives, or a grapevine figs. Neither can a saltwater spring produce fresh water.
The Wisdom That Comes Down from Above

Who \add is\add* wise and understanding among you? Let him show by his\ef + \fr 3:13 \ft ﻿*Literally “the”; the Greek article is used here as a possessive pronoun \ef* good behavior his works, with the humility of wisdom.
But if you have bitter jealousy and selfish ambition in your hearts, do not boast and tell lies against the truth.
This is not the wisdom that comes down from above, but \add is\add* earthly, unspiritual, demonic.
For where \add there is\add* jealousy and selfish ambition, there \add is\add* disorder and every evil practice.
But the wisdom from above is first pure, then peaceful, gentle, obedient, full of mercy and good fruits, nonjudgmental, without hypocrisy,
And the fruit of righteousness is sown in peace among\f + \fr 3:18 \ft Or “for”; or possibly “by” \f* those who make peace.
